author: @R3IMYSS
text: Which character are you training the system on? Franklin is the better driver, so it would be interesting to see if you can train the bot with Franklin and then see how it reacts to driving with Michael or Trevor.  :)    Just to explain a little more on that, so it makes it easier to drive with Franklin (you require less harsh turns to regain control of a vehicle), and if you drive with Michael or Trevor, you will find that you spin out more often and it is harder to control a car in general.   So if the system learns with Franklin, it'll kinda assume that it doesn't need to put THAT much effort into driving, but you'll surprise it when you play with Michael or Trevor.

author: @williambarnes5023
text: Don't just give the AI extra frames to increase its memory. Give it memory that it defines itself, so it can be "I want a byte here, and I'm going to set it to remember this thing I think is important." And maybe that byte is its speed, or where it last saw a cop, or whatever. We don't know what it needs or what it's thinking. That's why we evolve it. If it wants entire frames, it can claim memory and store them.

author: @KarfontaAlec
text: You're probably getting the same speed from the Pascal and Maxwell GPUs because gathering the experiences is CPU bound. If you're not doing this already you can do a replay memory where you store a queue of experiences and train on them multiple times. That way you can maximize the available GPU computation.

author: @Anaerin
text: Out of interest, why so complicated for the output? As I see it, you have 9 outputs (W, W+A, A, A+S, S, S+D, D, D+W and Nokeys). Surely this could be simplified to just W, A, S and D. Then if the NN wants to trigger W+A, it sets [1, 1, 0, 0] You could then decode with something like: --------8<---------------------------- if (inputs[0]) PressKey(W) else ReleaseKey(W) if (inputs[1]) PressKey(A) else ReleaseKey(A) if (inputs[2]) PressKey(S) else ReleaseKey(S) if (inputs[3]) PressKey(D) else ReleaseKey(D) --------8<---------------------------- Or if analog data is wanted/preferred, you could have 2 outputs, mapped to X and Y of a virtual analogue joystick.

author: @Toobiwoobi
text: this is an amazing piece of work, i absolutely love it and i think i have some ideas for improvements, which could be implemented pretty easily: 1. give it the possibility to use S to break, or maybe spacebar to use the handbrake 2. is it possible to simply feed the last 5 frames into the network as raw input instead of just taking the evaluated 5 frames and mix them to a output decision? if 5 frames were put into the network as input, it could maybe develop a kind of "feeling" for its actual speed, which in my opinion is critical to driving a vehicle 3. u could process the frames before u feed them into the model, for example black out the minimap so it wont influence the model or black out the upper quarter of the screen as there is only sky keep up the good work :D

author: @UnknownSquid
text: You know what this reminds me of? House flies and other simple insects. All actions based on simple stimuli and a short term memory barely a few seconds long. Training is the equivalent of evolution, and the current model at any point in time is any given flies individual instinct. What you need now, is for cars that successfully evade the police to multiply and diverge, and ones that fail or get stuck to die. Obviously that last bit is way beyond the scope of what's possible within GTA or normal hardware, but it's cool to think about.

author: @jhonmarshal6501
text: sentdex - is it possible to generate sloped lanes so the AI can determine what direction it's tires need to be at any given time? You could also use this to adjust for sharp turns by laying off the gas and to determine where it needs to position itself in its lane to increase constant speed and traction. Measuring the color or pattern of the lane lines may also help in better lane detection. There's a lot of math involved but this could increase the effectiveness of the AI greatly. Also traffic avoidance through vehicle recognition could determine the acceleration or velocity of traffic coming from its field of view which would also help avoid rear ending vehicles. If you can program to perceive depth you can tell how fast you are going in relation to those vehicles.  Another idea: what if the AI studied the behavior of surrounding vehicles to improve the ways that it itself works, this could be a much faster way of generating neural circuitry than the trial and error system you have set up.  You also should implement a system that helps the system more quickly learn from it's errors.  Note: I do not know how to program to this extent but I'm happy to collaborate in the format of these processes, I do have a good idea of how this would be coded I'm just not yet proficient enough in the hands on work that would need to be required.

author: @easyBob100
text: How noisy did you make the training data?  By that, I mean, did you crash into stuff, back up, and get back on the road (and other random things)?  If the model doesn't train on stuff like that, it won't know how to deal with things other than just driving on the road.  Once it goes off, it outputs junk.  Also, analog input would be better.  And while I'm commenting, more input controls to help the network generate output is good too.  Think of it like giving the network a 'goal'.  Maybe generate waypoints to drive to and use the minimap as input (so the network can "see" which way it needs to go).  Converting the minimap lines into an input vector would be a good input (if not really hard to do tho).  Best example would be Google's text to speech network.  When it has text to read, it sounds real, but when it doesn't, it sounds like gibberish. [/rant'n]

text: wouldn't just a few (5 -10) variable outputs that are fed as input in the next frame help creating a small memory? that way you wouldn't have to create a full recurrent network.

author: @johncusack3646
text: The reason for the same amount of training time might have to do with your ability to go from python to C++. You might want to try tfrecords for training data. And you might want to think about using knowledge transfer to lower training times and increases accuracy.
